intro: Acalypha arvensis var. pavoniana, commonly known as the red-veined nettle, is a herbaceous plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It features alternate, ovate leaves with prominent red veins that stand out against the green foliage. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in spikes, typical of the Euphorbiaceae family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed habitats. Its ornamental value is due to its striking leaf coloration and adaptability to various growing conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha arvensis var. pavoniana is primarily native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, including countries such as India, Thailand, and Malaysia. It is commonly found in moist, disturbed habitats like roadsides, fields, and along riverbanks. This variant is part of the Euphorbiaceae family and is known for its distinctive foliage and adaptability to various soil types. It thrives in warm climates with high humidity and is often seen in lowland areas. Its native range extends to parts of Africa and the Pacific Islands as well.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha arvensis var. pavoniana was mainly introduced to disturbed areas such as roadsides, fields, and urban environments. It thrives in nutrient-rich soils and can tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions. This plant is often found in areas with partial to full sunlight. Its rapid growth and ability to spread through seeds make it a common weed in agricultural and non-agricultural settings. It is considered an invasive species in some regions due to its competitive nature.
